lines.text: I mean, uh, what the heck you gonna shoot a .44 bullet at anyway... made out of silver?
How about a werewolf?
[Arnie the town drunk goes out to fix the train tracks in the middle of the night, becoming the first victim of the werewolf attacks]

[Arnie drunkenly sings]
My beer is Rheingold, the dry beer / Think of Rheingold whenever you buy beer / It's not bitter, not sweet, it's a real frosty treat / Won't you buy, won't you but Rheingold Beer / Won't you try, won't you buy

[Arnie hears the rustle of leaves]
Jesus, Arnie. What're you, are you afraid of the Boogeyman? Heh-heh. God. Come on out of there, buster, and give me a hand. All right, what is it that you want, Arnie? I want some Rheingold... As soon as I get that dirt out of there.

[narrating]
The killing had begun, but at first, no one knew it. You see, Arnie Westrum was a chronic drunk. And what happened seemed like an accident. The county coroner concluded Arnie had passed out on the tracks. There wasn't enough evidence to conclude anything else.
Aww, look out world, Marty the Great didn't get something he wanted.
Where's your Mom?
She and Dad are out back lighting the barbeque, yeah, and Jane's walking around in all these new clothes showing off her tits, acting like no one ever had tits before her.
[Marty rides alongside Tammy and gets her home, as the drunken father Milt Sturmfuller sees Marty]
Damn cripples. Always end up on welfare. Ought to electrocute them all. Balance the damn budget.
I feel like a virgin on prom night.
There are no such things as werewolves!
Ow! That's it. Oh, that hurts my parts.

[trying to explain having a silver bullet made]
My nephew has just discovered the Lone Ranger.
[Andy Fairton talks trash about Sheriff Haller not finding out about who murdered Stella Randolph]
Joe Haller couldn't find his own ass if somebody rammed it full of radium and gave him a Geiger counter!
[first lines]

[Older Jane narrating]
The last full moon of that Spring came a little more than a month before school let out for Summer vacation. Our town's long nightmare began that night.
[Older Jane narrates about the townspeople and her brother Marty]

[narrating at the scene of the town barbecue]
This is Tarker's Mills, where I grew up. And this is how it looked that Spring, a town where people cared about each other as much as they cared about themselves

[narrating at the scene of Marty]
I was nearly 15 years old, and my brother, Marty, was 11. Marty was the cross I had to bare. He wasn't so bad, actually. He was just constantly thrown in my face by my parents.
[Marty rides up to his friends Brady and Tammy at the end of school]
Hey, it's Madman Marty on the Silver Bullet! So, Marty, glad to be out of jail?
No. I like school.
Booger!
You wanna know what I think?
No, we just called you out here to admire your pretty little face.
You better watch your mouth, right now. You're on thin ice with me, son.
[Brady drops a garter snake from a tree above, getting Jane to fall into a puddle of mud]
Look alive!

[Marty covers his face as Brady continues to laugh at Jane]
Hey, Jane! Did you wet your pants?
Jane, I'm sorry.
Oh, yeah, sure!
I didn't mean to.
Oh, no. You never mean to! I hate you, you booger!
You know who used to have a baseball bat like that? Mr. Knopfler.
So?
It looked like Bigfoot had used it for a toothpick!
You always take his side 'cause he's crippled. Well, it's not my fault he's crippled!
You just wanna be quiet or I'm gonna smack you! Now, I mean it!
[Marty goes into Jane's room thinking she's asleep, when she see's Marty putting money down on her lamp table for she can get new pantyhose that Brady dirtied]

[Jane whispers in the dark]
What's the money for?
A new pair of pantyhose. Is it enough? Jane, please take the money. It was Brady's idea. Honest to God. I want to make up.

[Jane turns on the light]
I can get a pair of L'eggs down at the pharmacy for $1.49.
I told you, Babe, it ain't my baby - and don't you ever drag me off like that again!
Please, don't say that. You know it's your baby.
Look, we had this conversation before.
You know it better than anybody.
Sorry, Babe.
I have to have some help and I don't know what to do.
It's your oven but it ain't my bun ya got bakin' in there, huh? See ya.

[sobbing]
You have to help me.

[abandoning her]
Remember the good times, you know what I mean?
What's the matter, Bobby? You gonna make lemonade in your pants?
I ain't scared!
Holy jumped-up baldheaded Jesus palomino!
Uncle Red...

[to Jane then Marty then Jane again]
From him I'd expect it. Sometimes I think your common sense got paralyzed along with your legs. But from you, Jane - you're Miss Polly Practical!
You don't understand.
I understand that my niece and my nephew are sending little love notes to the local minister suggesting he gargle with broken glass or eat a rat-poison omelette!
This is for the good guys!
In the made-up stories, the guy who's the werewolf only changes when the moon is full, but maybe he's like this almost all the time, only as the moon gets fuller...
...the guy gets wolfier.
It's got a low-grain load, so it won't tumble.

[sees Marty stuck inside the condemned covered bridge]
Spooky in here, isn't it?

[after Jane and Marty tell him about the werewolf]
I'm a little too old to be playing "Hardy Boys meet Reverend Werewolf"!
You see, you meddling little shit!
[Stella Randolph cries in her bedroom with a handful of pills to overdose on]
Suicides go to hell, especially if they're pregnant, and I don't even care.
[as the werewolf makes its way up to her bedroom window]
Maybe that wasn't such a good idea telling that Smokey Bear from the detective division to 'fuck off', Joe.
Well, I waited till he hung up.
Where's it coming from? Over there?
No, it's behind us. I told you you couldn't trust this fog!
It's... under the fog!
What're you saying?
It's right here WITH us!
[more growling can be heard and Edgar is attacked; Maggie screams]

[petrified with fear]
I can't move!
Start backing up, Andy.
Yeah.
Real slow.
[Aspinall is attacked and Andy's gun goes off]

[to the mob, lead by Andy Fairton]
The law has a name for what you people are planning. It's called "private justice". And private justice is about a step and a half away from lynch mobs and hang ropes. Now I may be no J. Edgar Hoover, but I am the law in Tarker's Mills. I want all you people to go home.
Don't let this guy scare you! What's he done since this whole thing started but hang his face out? He ain't got so much as a fingerprint!
Shut up, Andy.
No, don't tell me to shut up.
Yes... Shut up. I just came from my boy's funeral.
Herb. Herb, I know how upset... how grief-stricken you must be.
He was torn apart.
I know that. I...
Upset? Grief-stricken? You don't know what those words mean. My son was torn to pieces. Pieces!
[shouts]

MY SON WAS TORN TO PIECES! You come in here and talk to these men about private justice? You dare to do that? Why do you go out to Harmony Hill, Sheriff Haller, and dig up what's left of my boy Brady... and explain to him about private justice. Would you want to do that? As for me, I'm gonna go out and hunt up a little private justice.
[walks out of the bar]

[to the mob]
You heard him. Let's go!
